_prev_prog_2.CT_OtherType: Inspected the liquid fertilizer blending plant with regards to the use of anhydrous ammonia in making fertilizers
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks and fertilizer blending plant

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: Grundy Co. LEPC, D Sheridan Roberts

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Snittjer Grain Co., Inc.
Wellsburg, IA

1. FACILITY POLICY:  The owners, management and employees of Snittjer Grain Co., Inc. (the facility) are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate and minimize the impacts of the release to people and the environment.

2. FACILITY INFORMATION:  The primary activity at the site relative to Risk Management Planning is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application and is used in the process of blending mixed-grade fertilizer for crop production nutrients.  It is stored at the facility in a storage tank with a capacity of 53,000 lbs. And nurse tanks totaling 184,000 pounds.  The total pounds of anhydrous capacity is 237,000 lbs.  A safety training program has been developed for the transfer of anhydrous ammonia in the blending of mixed-grade fertilizers.  Safety training will take place semi-annually with those individuals involved in the blending of mixed-grade fertilizers.

3. WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS:  A) The worst case scenario would be the release of the total contents of the storage tank as a gas over a period of 10 minutes.  The maximum quantity release would be 53,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the storage tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards.  The distance to the end point of dispersion of 200 parts per million, or ppm, is estimated to be about 1.8 miles.  B) The alternate case scenario, based on the five year accident history, or the most likely potential incident, is a break in a 3-inch transfer hose followed by release of ammonia for 2 minutes before an automatic or manual shut-off intervenes and stops the flow of ammonia.  The maximum quantity released would be 26,

600 lbs.  The distance to the end point of dispersion is estimated to be about 1.6 miles.

4. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:  The facility has been reviewed for general compliance with the provisions of Occupations Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Standard 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.  In addition, Standard K-61.1, Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia of the American National Standard Institute, Inc.  (ANSI) has been adopted by reference by Iowa Adminstrative Code (IAC) Part 21-Chapter 43-Rule 43.6(200), Standard for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia.

5. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:  There have been no accident releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuires or significaint property damage at the facility, nor, to the best of our knowledge, have resulted in any off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage or environmental damage.

6. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:  The facilty has: a) a written Emergency Action Plan in accordance with OHSA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 and b) provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).

7. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:  Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no additional specific safety recommendations regarding the storage or use of anhydrous ammonia for implementation at this time.
